content_for_placeholders.TITLE: An Overview of Digital Forensics
OBJECT: Definition: Applying investigative procedures for a legal purpose involving digital evidence.
Key Principles (per Ken Zatyko): Proper search authority, chain of custody, mathematical validation (hashing), and use of validated tools.
Global Standardization: ISO 27037 provides guidelines for identifying, collecting, and preserving digital evidence.
Legal Framework: The Fourth Amendment protects against unreasonable search and seizure, heavily influencing digital evidence collection.

content_for_placeholders.TITLE: An Overview of Digital Forensics
content_for_placeholders.SUBTITLE: Digital Forensics vs. Related Disciplines
OBJECT: Digital Forensics: Focuses on recovering hidden or deleted data as valid evidence.
Network Forensics: Traces attacker access and monitors network logs.
Data Recovery: Retrieves information lost accidentally; the target is known.
The Investigations Triad: Combines Investigations, Vulnerability Assessment, and Incident Response.

content_for_placeholders.TITLE: Activity for 'Related Disciplines'
OBJECT: A company's server crashes, and the accounting department needs to retrieve last month's financial reports. Is this primarily an act of digital forensics or data recovery?
content_for_placeholders.BODY: Answer: Data Recovery, because the goal is to restore known, non-hidden data lost accidentally.

content_for_placeholders.SUBTITLE: A Brief History of Digital Forensics

items.event: First forensics tools from government agencies emerge with PCs.
First commercial GUI tools like 'Expert Witness' appear.
Tools like EnCase and FTK handle large-scale storage.

content_for_placeholders.TITLE: Activity for 'History'
OBJECT: Why did PC growth in the 1980s necessitate formal digital forensics tools?
A) Mainframes were immune to electronic crime.
B) The variety of new OS and file types created new challenges.
C) All PCs came with built-in encryption.

OBJECT_LEFT.title: Key Principles
content: Case law is used when statutes don't exist for new tech.
Applies rulings from similar past cases to current ones.
Balances search needs with privacy expectations (4th Amendment).

OBJECT_RIGHT.title: Example: Commonwealth v. Copenhefer
content: Established that attempting to delete files does not automatically create a legally protected expectation of privacy.
A 'mere hope for secrecy' is not enough.

content_for_placeholders.TITLE: Activity for 'Case Law'

OBJECT_LEFT.title: Scenario
content: What is the primary function of case law in digital forensics?

OBJECT_RIGHT.title: Answer
content: To interpret how existing laws apply to new technologies and ambiguous situations, setting precedents for future cases.

content_for_placeholders.BODY: The answer highlights the adaptive nature of the legal system.

content_for_placeholders.TITLE: Summary & Key Takeaways
OBJECT: Digital forensics is a scientific process for legal purposes, distinct from data recovery.
The field has evolved from mainframe crimes to handling complex modern systems, guided by standards like ISO 27037.
Case law continuously adapts constitutional principles to new digital scenarios.
A successful investigator relies on a triad of skills: investigations, vulnerability assessment, and incident response.
